title: 104_s270
content: The "Alien Terrorist Removal Act of 1995" allows for the removal of alien terrorists under the Immigration and Nationality Act. Sec. 242C defines key terms such as 'alien terrorist', 'classified information', 'national security', 'special court', and 'special removal hearing'. The provisions of this section apply when the Attorney General certifies to the special court under seal. The provisions of section 242C apply when the Attorney General certifies to the special court that an alien terrorist is in the US and deportation proceedings would risk national security by disclosing classified information. The Chief Justice designates up to seven judges to hear cases under this section. The Chief Justice designates judges to hear cases under section 242C, consistent with the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act. A single judge of the special court considers applications in camera and ex parte if there is probable cause to believe the identified alien is a subject. The special removal hearing, authorized by a showing of probable cause, is open to the public. The alien has the right to be present and represented by counsel at the hearing. The alien in a special removal hearing has the right to be present, represented by counsel, introduce evidence, cross-examine witnesses, and request subpoenas. The judge can allow the introduction of classified evidence in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge in a special removal hearing can allow the introduction of classified evidence in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge must provide the alien with a substitution for the evidence or a summary if disclosure would pose a risk of harm to any person. In special removal hearings, classified evidence can be introduced in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge must provide the alien with a substitution for the evidence or a summary if disclosure would pose a risk of harm to any person. If the judge determines that the substituted evidence would provide the alien with the ability to make his defense or that disclosure would create a risk of harm, deportation may be determined accordingly. In special removal hearings, classified evidence can be introduced in camera if public disclosure poses a national security risk. The judge must provide the alien with a substitution for the evidence or a summary if disclosure would pose a risk of harm to any person. If the determination in subsection (e)(6)(A) or (e)(6)(B) has been made, the judge shall require deportation if the Attorney General proves, by clear and convincing evidence, that the alien is subject to deportation as described in section 241(a)(4)(B). Appeals can be made by the alien regarding the determination. The alien may appeal a determination under subsection (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The Attorney General may also appeal a determination under subsection (d), (e), or (f) to the court of appeals for the Federal Circuit within twenty days. The entire record of the proceeding under this section shall be transmitted to the court of appeals under seal when requested by the Attorney General.
